questions.text: Child age:
Gender:
Family history (select all that apply):
Does your child's ability to focus vary dramatically based on how interesting they find the activity?
questions.hint: For instance, can they play video games for hours but can't focus on homework for 10 minutes?

questions.text: Does your child have 'good days' and 'bad days' with attention, even when tasks and environment are similar?
questions.hint: Some days they can complete tasks, other days they can't, without obvious reason

questions.text: How does your child respond to new vs familiar situations?
options: Strongly prefers exciting new activities and gets bored with routines
Prefers new activities but can tolerate routines
Balanced - okay with both new and familiar
Prefers familiar routines but can handle some novelty
Strongly prefers familiar routines and becomes very distressed with unexpected changes

questions.text: How does your child respond to immediate rewards or incentives?
questions.hint: E.g., sticker charts, earning screen time, immediate praise
options: Dramatic improvement - they can focus much better with immediate rewards
Rewards seem to make things worse or create more conflict

questions.text: When does your child show the most intense focus and concentration?
options: On highly stimulating activities (games, screens, exciting play) regardless of educational value
On their specific interests (e.g., dinosaurs, trains, specific topics) regardless of stimulation level
Struggles to focus intensely on anything

questions.text: How would you describe your child's interest in friendships?
options: Really wants friends but struggles to keep them due to impulsive behavior (interrupting, not listening)
Wants friends but struggles due to not understanding social rules
Wants friends but too anxious or worried to maintain friendships
Generally prefers to play alone and seems content with limited social interaction
Avoids others due to mistrust or fear

questions.text: Describe your child's physical activity level:
options: Constantly moving, "driven by a motor", cannot sit still even briefly
Very active, fidgets constantly, difficulty sitting for meals/class
Moderately active, can sit when required but prefers movement
Lower activity than peers, seems sluggish or "in their own world"

questions.text: How does your child respond to structure and organization provided by others?
options: Functions much better when given clear structure, schedules, and external organization
Needs very predictable, unchanging routines and becomes upset with variations
Resists structure and fights against routines

questions.text: When your child doesn't complete tasks, what's usually the reason?
options: Gets distracted by other thoughts or activities
Finds the task boring or not stimulating enough
Becomes anxious or worried about doing it wrong
The task disrupts their preferred routine or interest

questions.text: Describe your child's emotional reactions:
options: Intense emotional reactions (frustration, excitement) that pass quickly
Becomes very upset when expectations are violated or things don't go as planned
Persistent worry or fearfulness that lasts for extended periods
Sudden fear responses, hypervigilance, or seems "on edge"

questions.text: How does your child communicate?
options: Talks excessively, interrupts, blurts out answers
One-sided conversations focused on their interests, difficulty with back-and-forth
Hesitant to speak, especially in new situations
Communication is typical for their age

questions.text: When your child's mind wanders or they seem distracted, what are they usually thinking about?
options: Random thoughts, daydreams, whatever pops into their head
Their specific interests or topics they love
Worries about school, friends, family, or what might go wrong
Seems checked out, dissociated, or numb

questions.text: When did you first notice these difficulties?
Did these difficulties begin after a specific event or were they always present?
options: Always been present, as long as I can remember
Gradually developed over time with no clear trigger
Began after a specific stressful event (loss, divorce, move, trauma)
Worsened after a specific event but some difficulties were always there

questions.text: Where do these difficulties occur? (Select all that apply)
Does your child have sleep difficulties?
options: Difficulty falling asleep but sleeps through the night
Snoring, gasping, or irregular breathing during sleep
Multiple sleep issues (trouble falling asleep, staying asleep, nightmares)

questions.text: Does your child have sensory sensitivities?
options: Extreme distress with certain textures, sounds, lights (e.g., tags in clothes, loud noises)
Seeks intense sensory input (spinning, crashing, loud sounds)

questions.text: How much do these behaviors interfere with academic performance?
How much do these behaviors affect friendships and social relationships?
How much do these behaviors affect family life and home functioning?
How is your child's self-esteem and emotional wellbeing?
